linkTarget.anchoringText: Yates is located 90 miles south of Midland, Texas, at the southeastern tip of the Central Basin Platform of the Permian Basin, as shown on the map in Figure 1. The field has produced from the Seven Rivers, Queen, and Grayburg formations, but the main producing formation is the San Andres carbonate, which is a naturally fractured, dolomite reservoir. The Yates Field structure is a broad and gently (1° to 4°) dipping,

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Yates Field Location at Southeastern tip of Central Basin Platform ( Button 2004 )

formatted-caption.caption-text: Yates Field Location at Southeastern tip of Central Basin Platform ( Button 2004 )

linkTarget.bib:
Button and Peterson, December 2004
P Button and C. Peterson
"Enhanced Gravity Drainage Through Immiscible CO2 Injection in the Yates Field (TX)". Presented at the 10th Annual CO2 Flood Conference, Midland, Texas, December 2004.

linkTarget.anchoringText: But after being deepened several times it tested at 3,036 barrels per hour (72,864 BOPD) in January, 1929. Most notable of the early wells was the Yates 30-A, which in September, 1929, tested at what was then the world record rate of 8,528 barrels per hour or 204,672 BOPD (Smith 2016). The YFU 4045 Hydrocarbon Miscible (HCM) Pilot is located within a mile of each of the aforementioned wells, as indicated on the Yates Field Top of San Andres Structure Map in Figure 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: YFU 4045 Pilot Location on Yates Field Top of San Andres Structure Map

formatted-caption.caption-text: YFU 4045 Pilot Location on Yates Field Top of San Andres Structure Map

linkTarget.anchoringText: Primary production was initially by volumetric expansion as the pressure dropped from 800 psi to the original bubble point of around 650 psi.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Yates East Side Area Primary Production Performance (1927 – 1976)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Yates East Side Area Primary Production Performance (1927 – 1976)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Produced gas was recycled back into the reservoir to mitigate the pressure decline beginning in July 1976. By injecting at the top of the structure the gas injection assisted the ongoing GOGD process.
linkTarget.label: Figure 4

image-wrap.caption: Yates East Side Area Secondary Production & Injection Performance (1976 – 2017)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Yates East Side Area Secondary Production & Injection Performance (1976 – 2017)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Since gas reservoir volume factors (3.0 RB/MSCF for CO2, 3.6 RB/MSCF for recycle gas) are high at the low Yates (640 psi in 2004) reservoir pressure, these increases in gas injection had a much larger effect on the reservoir processing rate at Yates than they would in the deeper, higher pressure reservoirs where CO2 has been injected elsewhere in the Permian Basin. Figure 5 shows how the reservoir production and injection rates increased from around 500,000 to 1,800,000 RBPD with the 2nd Phase of CO2 injection beginning in 2004. However, the oil cut as a percentage of the reservoir fluid production continued on its same hyperbolic decline, indicating that the production increase was not due to a miscible process.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Yates East Side Area Reservoir Processing Rate and % Oil Cut of Reservoir Fluid Production

formatted-caption.caption-text: Yates East Side Area Reservoir Processing Rate and % Oil Cut of Reservoir Fluid Production

linkTarget.anchoringText: Another field, the Rainbow Keg River B Field (Nagel 1988), was already on an established waterflood decline prior to the start of HCM injection, as shown by the data in Figure 6. After the HCM slug had been injected, there was a significant increase in both the oil rate and a flattening of the Reservoir Barrel (RB) oil cut decline. Incremental recovery from HCM injection in the Keg River B project is estimated to be around 12 percent of the OOIP, with a gross HCM utilization of around 1 STB/BBL HCM.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Incremental Tertiary Response to HCM Injection Exhibited at the Rainbow Keg River B Field in Alberta Canada

formatted-caption.caption-text: Incremental Tertiary Response to HCM Injection Exhibited at the Rainbow Keg River B Field in Alberta Canada

linkTarget.anchoringText: The YFU 4045 injector is bounded by three oil producing horizontal wells (YFU 4002, 4063, 4064), as shown in Figure 7. Selection of this pattern was also based on its definitive, historical response to CO2 injection and established areal connectivity.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: YFU 4045 HCM Pilot Area Map

formatted-caption.caption-text: YFU 4045 HCM Pilot Area Map

linkTarget.anchoringText: The YFU 4068 S-shaped well trajectory to its bottom hole location 177' W-NW of YFU 4045 is shown in Figure 8. The well was cased through the entire San Andres main pay and transition zone with fiberglass boron-free and metallic-free tubulars, collars, and pipe dope in order to allow induction resistivity logging. However, the primary logging measurements were performed using a carbon oxygen (C/O) pulsed neutron logging tool.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: YFU 4068 Logging Observation Well Trajectory to 177’ W-NW of YFU 4045

formatted-caption.caption-text: YFU 4068 Logging Observation Well Trajectory to 177’ W-NW of YFU 4045

linkTarget.anchoringText: The coreflood results are shown in Figure 9, which was conducted by injecting many volumes of immiscible CO2, followed by Y-Grade injection, which recovered incremental oil.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Yates Coreflood Results of CO2 followed by Y-Grade Injection

formatted-caption.caption-text: Yates Coreflood Results of CO2 followed by Y-Grade Injection

linkTarget.anchoringText: The oil production response has been favorable, with the oil rate impacted by the Y-Grade injection increasing from 47 BOPD up to a peak rate of 100 BOPD, as shown in Figure 10. During this initial Y- Grade injection period, YFU 4063ST1 and 4064ST1"s GOR's declined to the point where they could both produce continuously and were taken off the reactivation schedule. YFU 4064 was on reactivation for one day, shut-in for 6 days, then 2 days, shut-in for 5 days before falling below the field GOR cutoff and producing continuously thereafter.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: YFU 4045 HCM Pilot Well Production & Injection Rates

formatted-caption.caption-text: YFU 4045 HCM Pilot Well Production & Injection Rates

linkTarget.anchoringText: Although oil response from the Pilot was favorable, the cumulative oil and gas phase Y-Grade production was not equally distributed between the three producers. This is shown by the cumulative production through late June 2017 in Figure 11. The imbalance indicated that the areal sweep was misaligned, so the pilot wasn't providing an estimate of the true recovery potential of HCM injection at Yates.
linkTarget.label: Figure 11

image-wrap.caption: Cumulative Y-Grade & Oil Recovery by Well and Total for Pilot. Cumulative GP Y-Grade Production Cumulative Incremental Oil Production

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cumulative Y-Grade & Oil Recovery by Well and Total for Pilot. Cumulative GP Y-Grade Production Cumulative Incremental Oil Production

linkTarget.anchoringText: The frequent oil and gas sampling has provided compositional data giving insight into HCM displacement process and its efficiency at displacing oil in the reservoir. After all of the nitrogen and CO2 injected since 1976, the produced gas composition is mainly CO2, along with a smaller amount of nitrogen depending on the connectivity to CO2 injection wells. The CO2 compositions for the three Pilot producers are shown on the upper plot in Figure 12.
linkTarget.label: Figure 12

image-wrap.caption: Pilot Well CO2, Ethane, and Propane Produced Gas Composition Changes since Beginning Y-Grade Injection

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pilot Well CO2, Ethane, and Propane Produced Gas Composition Changes since Beginning Y-Grade Injection

linkTarget.anchoringText: Comparing the oil and gas compositional analyses also provides insight into how miscible displacement is occurring in the reservoir. In Figure 13, for each Pilot producer, the oil and gas compositional data is combined into Light, Intermediate, and Heavy component groupings:
linkTarget.label: Figure 13

image-wrap.caption: Oil & Gas Analysis of Light, Medium, & Heavy Component Grouping Performance

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil & Gas Analysis of Light, Medium, & Heavy Component Grouping Performance

linkTarget.anchoringText: Pilot Y-Grade injection, chase CO2 injection, and oil and Y-Grade production performance are shown in Figure 14. Incremental oil recovery above the base decline is observed within a month of beginning Y- Grade injection in November 2016, while the theoretical Y-Grade recovery occurs around two months after Y-Grade injection. Oil production peaked at around 100 BOPD in April 2017, and it appears to have been starting to decline when Y-Grade injection was completed in May 2017, while Y-Grade production continued to incline through the end of Y-Grade injection.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: YFU 4045 HCM Pilot Oil Production, Y-Grade Production & Injection, and CO2 Injection

formatted-caption.caption-text: YFU 4045 HCM Pilot Oil Production, Y-Grade Production & Injection, and CO2 Injection

linkTarget.anchoringText: The interpretations of several of these monitor logging runs are shown in Figure 15, along with the YFU 4068 porosity curve, and the four major logging interval designations. The upper most interval includes the Queen and Grayburg tie-in intervals, so named because they are lower intervals where little if any fluid saturation changes were anticipated. Then there is the Secondary Gas Cap interval, which is the thickest interval with the highest porosity, and should be where the largest remaining residual oil target exists.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: YFU 4068 Monitor Logging Well Time-lapsed Oil Saturations, Porosity, and 4 Major Logging Interval Designations

formatted-caption.caption-text: YFU 4068 Monitor Logging Well Time-lapsed Oil Saturations, Porosity, and 4 Major Logging Interval Designations

linkTarget.anchoringText: The calculated oil saturations from the monthly monitor logs were averaged across the HCM Processed Interval, and are shown plotted with time in Figure 16. The six months of Y-Grade injection appears to have reduced the oil saturation by 8-10 percent. In comparison, the shallower San Andres reservoir above the HCM injection exhibited much less oil desaturation.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: YFU 4068 Monitor Logging Average Oil Saturation in HCM Processed interval

formatted-caption.caption-text: YFU 4068 Monitor Logging Average Oil Saturation in HCM Processed interval

linkTarget.anchoringText: A fully compositional, dual permeability model was developed to study the YFU 4045 HCM Pilot performance. A 30 × 39 × 47 grid was used, as shown in Figure 17. Well trajectories were input based on their HDH deviation surveys. The layers are areally homomogeneous, but are varied vertically by tying to the YFU 4045 porosity curve. Permeabilities were calculated from the field k-phi transform. The resulting average layer properties are shown in Figure 18, overlaying the YFU 4045 porosity and k-phi transform calculated permeability.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: YFU 4045 HCM Pilot Area Map & Model Grid

formatted-caption.caption-text: YFU 4045 HCM Pilot Area Map & Model Grid

linkTarget.anchoringText: A fully compositional, dual permeability model was developed to study the YFU 4045 HCM Pilot performance. A 30 × 39 × 47 grid was used, as shown in Figure 17. Well trajectories were input based on their HDH deviation surveys. The layers are areally homomogeneous, but are varied vertically by tying to the YFU 4045 porosity curve. Permeabilities were calculated from the field k-phi transform. The resulting average layer properties are shown in Figure 18, overlaying the YFU 4045 porosity and k-phi transform calculated permeability.
linkTarget.label: Figure 18

image-wrap.caption: YFU 4045 Porosity & Transform Calculated Permeability, Overlaid by Reservoir Model Layer Properties Porosity (%) Permeability (md)

formatted-caption.caption-text: YFU 4045 Porosity & Transform Calculated Permeability, Overlaid by Reservoir Model Layer Properties Porosity (%) Permeability (md)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Increasing the porosity also reduced the Y-Grade back production to allow it to match the actual performance, as shown by Figure 19. Without this change, the model Y- Grade back production was around twice the actual rate, because the Y-Grade moved down the fractures with little entering the matrix. With the higher permeability, more Y- Grade was absorbed into the matrix, reducing the Y-Grade back production.

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Back Produced Y-Grade History Match

formatted-caption.caption-text: Back Produced Y-Grade History Match

linkTarget.anchoringText: When this entire 1000 feet (21 grid blocks) of completion was opened in the model, total fluid production was far too high. Reducing the number of open grid blocks to 6 (every 4th block being open) resulted in a more representative total fluid rate. The GOR was too low and WOR too high, so the well was completed two layers shallower in the model, resulting in the history match shown in Figure 20. The oil-water contact appears to be lower in this part of the model area. An improved reservoir description should improve this match quality.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: YFU 4063ST2 HDH Lateral Production History Match & Forecast

formatted-caption.caption-text: YFU 4063ST2 HDH Lateral Production History Match & Forecast

linkTarget.anchoringText: The resulting history match is shown by the injection and production plots in Figure 21
linkTarget.label: Figure 21

image-wrap.caption: YFU 4045 Injection & Production History Match Pilot Injection Pilot Production

formatted-caption.caption-text: YFU 4045 Injection & Production History Match Pilot Injection Pilot Production

linkTarget.anchoringText: The YFU 4045 HCM Pilot produced incremental tertiary oil. By history matching the reservoir performance the model can be used to explain how the Y-Grade is processed in the reservoir. Figure 22 illustrates how the model predicts the Y-Grade has swept the reservoir through the beginning of 2018. The global mole fraction of ethane, a major component of Y-Grade, is used as a proxy for the Y-Grade concentration.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: Visualization of Model Forecast Global Ethane Composition showing the Extent of Y-Grade Sweep of the Reservoir

formatted-caption.caption-text: Visualization of Model Forecast Global Ethane Composition showing the Extent of Y-Grade Sweep of the Reservoir

linkTarget.anchoringText: The model forecast oil production in Figure 21 is shown to exceed the historical oil rate during the initial Y-Grade injection period from November 2016 to July 2017. So for calculating the Y-Grade utilization, the incremental oil rate was reduced by a factor of 75 percent, as shown in Figure 23. Using the actual Pilot Y-Grade injection volume, the 75 percent adjusted incremental oil rate forecast, and the Y-Grade recovery forecast shown in Figure 17, the estimated gross and net YFU 4045 HCM Pilot Y-Grade utilizations are those calculated in Table 2.

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: YFU 4045 HCM Pilot Oil Production History Match and Forecast

formatted-caption.caption-text: YFU 4045 HCM Pilot Oil Production History Match and Forecast
